title: What’s the origin of the term, “in my wheelhouse”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well I just used that term in an earlier response, so I looked it up earlier today, wondering the same question. Turns out the wheel in question is a very big wheel, as in the side-wheeled paddle boats that used to ply the Mississippi River (and were written about so engagingly by Mark Twain in his Life on the Mississippi). The housing that covered the out-of-water portion of the wheel was called its “wheel house.” The interesting implication of the phrase, which I’m sure has made it especially popular among tv talking heads on political topics, is that anything INSIDE the wheelhouse will be addressed with considerable force. So it’s become a not-so-subtle way of patting oneself on the back (“just wait till you ask me a question that IS in my wheelhouse!”) while appearing to be circumspect and deferential.

It is an idiom (in one’s/my wheelhouse): Baseball: (of a pitch) within the zone that is most advantageous for a batter to hit a home run. Within one’s area of expertise or interest: ‘There are some subjects that are in your wheelhouse and some that are not.’ https://www.dictionary.com/browse/wheelhouse
